reason: Inducing a female Chinese alligator to bellow in an airtight chamber filled with helium-enriched air.

resources.name: A Chinese Alligator in Heliox: Formant Frequencies in a Crocodilian

reason: Devising a method to identify narcissists by examining their eyebrows.
Having their diplomats surreptitiously ring each other’s doorbells in the middle of the night, and then run away before anyone had a chance to answer the door.
Determining, experimentally, what happens to the shape of a living earthworm when one vibrates the earthworm at high frequency.

resources.name: Excitation of Faraday-like body waves in vibrated living earthworms

reason: Trying to quantify the relationship between different countries’ national income inequality and the average amount of mouth-to-mouth kissing.

resources.name: National Income Inequality Predicts Cultural Variation in Mouth to Mouth Kissing

reason: A hit job (a murder performed for money) in the following way: After accepting payment to perform the murder, Xi Guang-An then instead subcontracted the task to Mo Tian-Xiang, who then instead subcontracted the task to Yang Kang-Sheng, who then instead subcontracted the task to Yang Guang-Sheng, who then instead subcontracted the task to Ling Xian-Si, with each subsequently enlisted hitman receiving a smaller percentage of the fee, and nobody actually performing a murder.
Collecting evidence that many entomologists (scientists who study insects) are afraid of spiders, which are not insects.

resources.name: Arachnophobic Entomologists: When Two More Legs Makes a Big Difference

reason: Diagnosing a long-unrecognized medical condition: Misophonia, the distress at hearing other people make chewing sounds.

resources.name: Misophonia: Diagnostic Criteria for a New Psychiatric Disorder
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy is Effective in Misophonia: An Open Trial

reason: Using the Covid-19 viral pandemic to teach the world that politicians can have a more immediate effect on life and death than scientists and doctors can.
Showing that knives manufactured from frozen human feces do not work well.

resources.name: Metin Eren, Michelle Bebber, James Norris, Alyssa Perrone, Ashley Rutkoski, Michael Wilson, and Mary Ann Raghanti
Experimental Replication Shows Knives Manufactured from Frozen Human Feces Do Not Work

reason: Collecting evidence that pizza might protect against illness and death, if the pizza is made and eaten in Italy.

resources.name: Pizza and Risk of Acute Myocardial Infarction
Pizza Consumption and the Risk of Breast, Ovarian and Prostate Cancer

reason: Using a simple animal-training technique— called “clicker training” —to train surgeons to perform orthopedic surgery.

resources.name: Is Teaching Simple Surgical Skills Using an Operant Learning Program More Effective Than Teaching by Demonstration

reason: Discovering that dead magnetized cockroaches behave differently than living magnetized cockroaches.

resources.name: In-Vivo Biomagnetic Characterisation of the American Cockroach

reason: Measuring scrotal temperature asymmetry in naked and clothed postmen in France.

resources.name: Thermal Asymmetry of the Human Scrotum

reason: Estimating the total saliva volume produced per day by a typical five-year-old child

resources.name: Estimation of the Total Saliva Volume Produced Per Day in Five-Year-Old Children

reason: Inventing a diaper-changing machine for use on human infants.

resources.name: diaper-changing machine for use on human infants
Infant Washer and Diaper-Changer Apparatus and Method

reason: Testing which country’s paper money is best at transmitting dangerous bacteria.
Trying to measure the pleasurability of scratching an itch.

resources.name: The Pleasurability of Scratching an Itch: A Psychophysical and Topographical Assessment

reason: Discovering that holding a pen in one’s mouth makes one smile, which makes one happier — and for then discovering that it does not.

resources.name: Inhibiting and facilitating conditions of the human smile: a nonobtrusive test of the facial feedback hypothesis
From Data to Truth in Psychological Science. A Personal Perspective

reason: Studying how, and why, wombats make cube-shaped poo.

resources.name: How Do Wombats Make Cubed Poo?

reason: Using roller coaster rides to try to hasten the passage of kidney stones.
Collecting evidence, in a zoo, that chimpanzees imitate humans about as often, and about as well, as humans imitate chimpanzees.
Demonstrating that wine experts can reliably identify, by smell, the presence of a single fly in a glass of wine.
Measuring the degree to which human saliva is a good cleaning agent for dirty surfaces.
The medical report “Colonoscopy in the Sitting Position: Lessons Learned From Self-Colonoscopy.”
Documenting that most people who use complicated products do not read the instruction manual.
Calculating that the caloric intake from a human-cannibalism diet is significantly lower than the caloric intake from most other traditional meat diets.
Measuring the frequency, motivation, and effects of shouting and cursing while driving an automobile.
Using postage stamps to test whether the male sexual organ is functioning properly—as described in their study “Nocturnal Penile Tumescence Monitoring With Stamps.”
Investigating whether it is effective for employees to use Voodoo dolls to retaliate against abusive bosses.
Using fluid dynamics to probe the question “Can a Cat Be Both a Solid and a Liquid?”
Demonstrating that regular playing of a didgeridoo is an effective treatment for obstructive sleep apnoea and snoring.
Their experiments to see how contact with a live crocodile affects a person’s willingness to gamble.
His medical research study “Why Do Old Men Have Big Ears?”
Their discovery of a female penis, and a male vagina, in a cave insect.

Studying the dynamics of liquid-sloshing, to learn what happens when a person walks backwards while carrying a cup of coffee. REFERENCE: “A Study on the Coffee Spilling Phenomena in the Low Impulse Regime,” Jiwon Han, Achievements in the Life Sciences, vol. 10, no. 1, 2016, pp. 87-101.

resources.name: A Study on the Coffee Spilling Phenomena in the Low Impulse Regime

reason: The first scientific report of human blood in the diet of the hairy-legged vampire bat
Using advanced brain-scanning technology to measure the extent to which some people are disgusted by cheese.
Demonstrating that many identical twins cannot tell themselves apart visually.

Showing that a developing human fetus responds more strongly to music that is played electromechanically inside the mother’s vagina than to music that is played electromechanically on the mother’s belly.
Studying the effects of wearing polyester, cotton, or wool trousers on the sex life of rats, and for conducting similar tests with human males.
Assessing the perceived personalities of rocks, from a sales and marketing perspective.
Discovering why white-haired horses are the most horsefly-proof horses, and for discovering why dragonflies are fatally attracted to black tombstones.
Solving the problem of excessive automobile pollution emissions by automatically, electromechanically producing fewer emissions whenever the cars are being tested.
Discovering that if you have an itch on the left side of your body, you can relieve it by looking into a mirror and scratching the right side of your body (and vice versa).
Asking a thousand liars how often they lie, and for deciding whether to believe those answers.
Their scholarly study called “On the Reception and Detection of Pseudo-Profound Bullshit”.

Living in the wild as, at different times, a badger, an otter, a deer, a fox, and a bird; and to Thomas Thwaites, for creating prosthetic extensions of his limbs that allowed him to move in the manner of, and spend time roaming hills in the company of, goats.
His three-volume autobiographical work about the pleasures of collecting flies that are dead, and flies that are not yet dead.
Investigating whether things look different when you bend over and view them between your legs.
Inventing a chemical recipe to partially un-boil an egg.
Testing the biological principle that nearly all mammals empty their bladders in about 21 seconds (plus or minus 13 seconds).
Discovering that the word “huh?” (or its equivalent) seems to exist in every human language — and for not being completely sure why.

Discovering that many business leaders developed during childhood a fondness for risk-taking, when they experienced natural disasters (such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, tsunamis, and wildfires) that — for them — had no dire personal consequences.
Offering to pay policemen extra cash if the policemen refuse to take bribes.
Experiments to study the biomedical benefits or biomedical consequences of intense kissing (and other intimate, interpersonal activities).

Trying to use mathematical techniques to determine whether and how Moulay Ismael the Bloodthirsty, the Sharifian Emperor of Morocco, managed, during the years from 1697 through 1727, to father 888 children.
Observing that when you attach a weighted stick to the rear end of a chicken, the chicken then walks in a manner similar to that in which dinosaurs are thought to have walked.
Determining that acute appendicitis can be accurately diagnosed by the amount of pain evident when the patient is driven over speed bumps.

Painstakingly creating the Schmidt Sting Pain Index, which rates the relative pain people feel when stung by various insects; and to Michael L. Smith [PANAMA, US, UK, THE NETHERLANDS], for carefully arranging for honey bees to sting him repeatedly on 25 different locations on his body, to learn which locations are the least painful (the skull, middle toe tip, and upper arm). and which are the most painful (the nostril, upper lip, and penis shaft).
Measuring the amount of friction between a shoe and a banana skin, and between a banana skin and the floor, when a person steps on a banana skin that’s on the floor.
Trying to understand what happens in the brains of people who see the face of Jesus in a piece of toast.
Amassing evidence that people who habitually stay up late are, on average, more self-admiring, more manipulative, and more psychopathic than people who habitually arise early in the morning.
Investigating whether it is mentally hazardous for a human being to own a cat.
Carefully documenting that when dogs defecate and urinate, they prefer to align their body axis with Earth’s north-south geomagnetic field lines.
Measuring the relative pain people suffer while looking at an ugly painting, rather than a pretty painting, while being shot [in the hand] by a powerful laser beam.

Proudly taking the lead in fulfilling the European Union mandate for each country to increase the official size of its national economy by including revenues from prostitution, illegal drug sales, smuggling, and all other unlawful financial transactions between willing participants.
Treating “uncontrollable” nosebleeds, using the method of nasal-packing-with-strips-of-cured-pork.
Testing how reindeer react to seeing humans who are disguised as polar bears.
Their study titled “Characterization of Lactic Acid Bacteria Isolated from Infant Faeces as Potential Probiotic Starter Cultures for Fermented Sausages.”

resources.name: Characterization of Lactic Acid Bacteria Isolated from Infant Faeces as Potential Probiotic Starter Cultures for Fermented Sausages

reason: Assessing the effect of listening to opera, on heart transplant patients who are mice.
Confirming, by experiment, that people who think they are drunk also think they are attractive.

type: JOINT PRIZE IN BIOLOGY AND AST
reason: Discovering that when dung beetles get lost, they can navigate their way home by looking at the Milky Way.

resources.name: navigate their way home by looking at the Milky Way

reason: Inventing an electro-mechanical system to trap airplane hijackers — the system drops a hijacker through trap doors, seals him into a package, then drops the encapsulated hijacker through the airplane’s specially-installed bomb bay doors, whence he parachutes to earth, where police, having been alerted by radio, await his arrival. US Patent #3811643, Gustano A. Pizzo, “anti hijacking system for aircraft”, May 21, 1972.

resources.name: US Patent #3811643, Gustano A. Pizzo, “anti hijacking system for aircraft”

reason: Discovering that some people would be physically capable of running across the surface of a pond — if those people and that pond were on the moon.
Discovering that the biochemical process by which onions make people cry is even more complicated than scientists previously realized.

Parboiling a dead shrew, and then swallowing the shrew without chewing, and then carefully examining everything excreted during subsequent days — all so they could see which bones would dissolve inside the human digestive system, and which bones would not.
Making it illegal to applaud in public, AND to the Belarus State Police, for arresting a one-armed man for applauding.

resources.name: making it illegal to applaud in public
arresting a one-armed man for applauding

reason: Making two related discoveries: First, that the longer a cow has been lying down, the more likely that cow will soon stand up; and Second, that once a cow stands up, you cannot easily predict how soon that cow will lie down again.

The medical techniques described in their report “Surgical Management of an Epidemic of Penile Amputations in Siam” — techniques which they recommend, except in cases where the amputated penis had been partially eaten by a duck. [THAILAND]
Their study “Leaning to the Left Makes the Eiffel Tower Seem Smaller”
Converting old Russian ammunition into new diamonds.

resources.name: converting old Russian ammunition into new diamonds

reason: Creating the SpeechJammer — a machine that disrupts a person’s speech, by making them hear their own spoken words at a very slight delay.
Demonstrating that brain researchers, by using complicated instruments and simple statistics, can see meaningful brain activity anywhere — even in a dead salmon.
Solving the puzzle of why, in certain houses in the town of Anderslöv, Sweden, people’s hair turned green.
Issuing a report about reports about reports that recommends the preparation of a report about the report about reports about reports.
Calculating the balance of forces that shape and move the hair in a human ponytail.
Studying the dynamics of liquid-sloshing, to learn what happens when a person walks while carrying a cup of coffee.
Discovering that chimpanzees can identify other chimpanzees individually from seeing photographs of their rear ends.
Advising doctors who perform colonoscopies how to minimize the chance that their patients will explode.
Their study “No Evidence of Contagious Yawning in the Red-Footed Tortoise.”

resources.name: No Evidence of Contagious Yawning in the Red-Footed Tortoise

reason: Determining the ideal density of airborne wasabi (pungent horseradish) to awaken sleeping people in case of a fire or other emergency, and for applying this knowledge to invent the wasabi alarm.
Demonstrating that people make better decisions about some kinds of things — but worse decisions about other kinds of things‚ when they have a strong urge to urinate.
Trying to understand why, in everyday life, people sigh.
His Theory of Structured Procrastination, which says: To be a high achiever, always work on something important, using it as a way to avoid doing something that’s even more important.
Discovering that a certain kind of beetle mates with a certain kind of Australian beer bottle
Determining why discus throwers become dizzy, and why hammer throwers don’t.
Teaching the world to be careful when making mathematical assumptions and calculations.
Demonstrating that the problem of illegally parked luxury cars can be solved by running them over with an armored tank.
Conducting a series of safety experiments in which a person drives an automobile on a major highway while a visor repeatedly flaps down over his face, blinding him.
Perfecting a method to collect whale snot, using a remote-control helicopter.

resources.name: a method to collect whale snot, using a remote-control helicopter

reason: Discovering that symptoms of asthma can be treated with a roller-coaster ride.
Using slime mold to determine the optimal routes for railroad tracks.
Demonstrating that, on icy footpaths in wintertime, people slip and fall less often if they wear socks on the outside of their shoes.
Confirming the widely held belief that swearing relieves pain.
Determining by experiment that microbes cling to bearded scientists.
Creating and promoting new ways to invest money — ways that maximize financial gain and minimize financial risk for the world economy, or for a portion thereof.
Disproving the old belief that oil and water don’t mix.
Demonstrating mathematically that organizations would become more efficient if they promoted people at random.
Scientifically documenting fellatio in fruit bats.
Showing that cows who have names give more milk than cows that are nameless.
Determining — by experiment — whether it is better to be smashed over the head with a full bottle of beer or with an empty bottle.
Demonstrating that tiny banks can be rapidly transformed into huge banks, and vice versa — and for demonstrating that similar things can be done to an entire national economy.
Creating diamonds from liquid — specifically from tequila.

Investigating a possible cause of arthritis of the fingers, by diligently cracking the knuckles of his left hand — but never cracking the knuckles of his right hand — every day for more than sixty (60) years.
Analytically determining why pregnant women don’t tip over.
Writing and presenting more than fifty traffic tickets to the most frequent driving offender in the country — Prawo Jazdy — whose name in Polish means “Driving License”.
Inventing a brassiere that, in an emergency, can be quickly converted into a pair of protective face masks, one for the brassiere wearer and one to be given to some needy bystander.

resources.name: brassiere that, in an emergency, can be quickly converted into a pair of protective face masks

reason: Giving people a simple, everyday way to cope with a wide range of numbers — from very small to very big — by having his bank print bank notes with denominations ranging from one cent ($.01) to one hundred trillion dollars ($100,000,000,000,000).
Demonstrating that kitchen refuse can be reduced more than 90% in mass by using bacteria extracted from the feces of giant pandas.
Electronically modifying the sound of a potato chip to make the person chewing the chip believe it to be crisper and fresher than it really is.

resources.name: the sound of a potato chip

reason: Adopting the legal principle that plants have dignity.

resources.name: The Swiss Federal Ethics Committee on Non-Human Biotechnology (ECNH)

reason: Measuring how the course of history, or at least the contents of an archaeological dig site, can be scrambled by the actions of a live armadillo.
Discovering that the fleas that live on a dog can jump higher than the fleas that live on a cat.
University (USA), and Ziv Carmon of INSEAD (Singapore) for demonstrating that high-priced fake medicine is more effective than low-priced fake medicine..
Discovering that slime molds can solve puzzles.
Discovering that professional lap dancers earn higher tips when they are ovulating.
Proving mathematically that heaps of string or hair or almost anything else will inevitably tangle themselves up in knots.
Discovering that Coca-Cola is an effective spermicide, and to Chuang-Ye Hong of Taipei Medical University (Taiwan), C.C. Shieh, P. Wu, and B.N. Chiang (all of Taiwan) for discovering that it is not.
His lovingly written study “You Bastard: A Narrative Exploration of the Experience of Indignation within Organizations.”
Their penetrating medical report “Sword Swallowing and Its Side Effects.”

resources.name: Sword Swallowing and Its Side Effects

reason: Studying how sheets become wrinkled.
Doing a census of all the mites, insects, spiders, pseudoscorpions, crustaceans, bacteria, algae, ferns and fungi with whom we share our beds each night.

resources.name: Prof. Dr. Johanna E.M.H. van Bronswijk

reason: Developing a way to extract vanillin — vanilla fragrance and flavoring — from cow dung.
Showing that rats sometimes cannot tell the difference between a person speaking Japanese backwards and a person speaking Dutch backwards.
Her study of the word “the” — and of the many ways it causes problems for anyone who tries to put things into alphabetical order.
Instigating research & development on a chemical weapon — the so-called “gay bomb” — that will make enemy soldiers become sexually irresistible to each other.
Exploring the seemingly boundless appetites of human beings, by feeding them with a self-refilling, bottomless bowl of soup.
Patenting a device, in the year 2001, that catches bank robbers by dropping a net over them.
Their discovery that Viagra aids jetlag recovery in hamsters.
Exploring and explaining why woodpeckers don’t get headaches.
Showing that dung beetles are finicky eaters.

Inventing an electromechanical teenager repellant — a device that makes annoying high-pitched noise designed to be audible to teenagers but not to adults; and for later using that same technology to make telephone ringtones that are audible to teenagers but probably not to their teachers.

resources.name: device that makes annoying high-pitched noise designed to be audible to teenagers but not to adults
telephone ringtones that are audible to teenagers but probably not to their teachers

reason: Conducting experiments to learn why people dislike the sound of fingernails scraping on a blackboard.
Calculating the number of photographs you must take to (almost) ensure that nobody in a group photo will have their eyes closed

resources.name: Australian Commonwealth Scientific and Research Organization

reason: His report “Consequences of Erudite Vernacular Utilized Irrespective of Necessity: Problems with Using Long Words Needlessly.”

resources.name: Consequences of Erudite Vernacular Utilized Irrespective of Necessity: Problems with Using Long Words Needlessly

reason: His medical case report “Termination of Intractable Hiccups with Digital Rectal Massage“; and Majed Odeh, Harry Bassan, and Arie Oliven of Bnai Zion Medical Center, Haifa, Israel, for their subsequent medical case report also titled “Termination of Intractable Hiccups with Digital Rectal Massage.”

resources.name: Termination of Intractable Hiccups with Digital Rectal Massage

reason: Their insights into why, when you bend dry spaghetti, it often breaks into more than two pieces.
Their study “Ultrasonic Velocity in Cheddar Cheese as Affected by Temperature.”

Medical Research, in Ifakara Centre, Tanzania, and of the International Atomic Energy Agency, in Vienna Austria) and Ruurd de Jong (of Wageningen Agricultural University and of Santa Maria degli Angeli, Italy) for showing that the female malaria mosquito Anopheles gambiae is attracted equally to the smell of limburger cheese and to the smell of human feet.
His scholarly study, “The Significance of Mr. Richard Buckley’s Exploding Trousers. ”

resources.name: The Significance of Mr. Richard Buckley’s Exploding Trousers

reason: Patiently conducting an experiment that began in the year 1927 — in which a glob of congealed black tar has been slowly, slowly dripping through a funnel, at a rate of approximately one drop every nine years.
Inventing Neuticles — artificial replacement testicles for dogs, which are available in three sizes, and three degrees of firmness.

Creating and then using e-mail to distribute a bold series of short stories, thus introducing millions of readers to a cast of rich characters — General Sani Abacha, Mrs. Mariam Sanni Abacha, Barrister Jon A Mbeki Esq., and others — each of whom requires just a small amount of expense money so as to obtain access to the great wealth to which they are entitled and which they would like to share with the kind person who assists them.

resources.name: a bold series of short stories

reason: Electrically monitoring the activity of a brain cell in a locust while that locust was watching selected highlights from the movie “Star Wars.”

resources.name: electrically monitoring the activity of a brain cell

reason: Inventing an alarm clock that runs away and hides, repeatedly, thus ensuring that people DO get out of bed, and thus theoretically adding many productive hours to the workday.

resources.name: an alarm clock that runs away and hides, repeatedly

reason: Conducting a careful experiment to settle the longstanding scientific question: can people swim faster in syrup or in water?
Painstakingly smelling and cataloging the peculiar odors produced by 131 different species of frogs when the frogs were feeling stressed.
Photographing and retrospectively analyzing every meal he has consumed during a period of 34 years (and counting).[See the movie “The Invention of Dr. Nakamats“, 2009]
Using basic principles of physics to calculate the pressure that builds up inside a penguin, as detailed in their report “Pressures Produced When Penguins Pooh — Calculations on Avian Defaecation.”

resources.name: Pressures Produced When Penguins Pooh — Calculations on Avian Defaecation

reason: Their published report “The Effect of Country Music on Suicide.”

resources.name: The Effect of Country Music on Suicide

reason: Exploring and explaining the dynamics of hula-hooping.
Investigating the scientific validity of the Five-Second Rule about whether it’s safe to eat food that’s been dropped on the floor.

resources.name: Chicago High School for Agricultural Sciences
investigating the scientific validity of the Five-Second Rule

reason: Using advanced technology to convert ordinary tap water into Dasani, a transparent form of water, which for precautionary reasons has been made unavailable to consumers.

resources.name: The Coca-Cola Company of Great Britain
Dasani, a transparent form of water, which for precautionary reasons has been made unavailable to consumers

reason: Patenting the combover (U.S. Patent #4,022,227).

resources.name: Donald J. Smith and his father, the late Frank J. Smith

reason: Preserving nudist history so that everyone can see it.
Demonstrating that when people pay close attention to something, it’s all too easy to overlook anything else — even a woman in a gorilla suit.
Outsourcing prayers to India.
Inventing karaoke, thereby providing an entirely new way for people to learn to tolerate each other.
Showing that herrings apparently communicate by farting.

Jointly giving birth in 1949 to Murphy’s Law, the basic engineering principle that “If there are two or more ways to do something, and one of those ways can result in a catastrophe, someone will do it “(or, in other words: “If anything can go wrong, it will”).
Their irresistible report “An Analysis of the Forces Required to Drag Sheep over Various Surfaces.”

resources.name: An Analysis of the Forces Required to Drag Sheep over Various Surfaces

reason: Presenting evidence that the brains of London taxi drivers are more highly developed than those of their fellow citizens.
Their discerning report “Politicians’ Uniquely Simple Personalities.”
His chemical investigation of a bronze statue, in the city of Kanazawa, that fails to attract pigeons.

resources.name: chemical investigation of a bronze statue, in the city of Kanazawa

reason: Meticulously collecting data and publishing more than 80 detailed academic reports about things that annoyed him
Making it possible to rent the entire country for corporate conventions, weddings, bar mitzvahs, and other gatherings.
Their inevitable report “Chickens Prefer Beautiful Humans.”

A triple accomplishment: First, for leading an active life even though he has been declared legally dead; Second, for waging a lively posthumous campaign against bureaucratic inertia and greedy relatives; and Third, for creating the Association of Dead People.

resources.name: leading an active life even though he has been declared legally dead

reason: Documenting the first scientifically recorded case of homosexual necrophilia in the mallard duck.
Their report “Courtship Behaviour of Ostriches Towards Humans Under Farming Conditions in Britain.”

resources.name: Courtship Behaviour of Ostriches Towards Humans Under Farming Conditions in Britain

reason: Demonstrating that beer froth obeys the mathematical Law of Exponential Decay.
Performing a comprehensive survey of human belly button lint — who gets it, when, what color, and how much.

resources.name: comprehensive survey of human belly button lint

reason: Gathering many elements of the periodic table, and assembling them into the form of a four-legged periodic table table.

Their analytical report “Estimation of the Total Surface Area in Indian Elephants.” [REFERENCE: “Estimation of the Total Surface Area in Indian Elephants (Elephas maximus indicus),” K.P. Sreekumar and G. Nirmalan, Veterinary Research Communications, vol. 14, no. 1, 1990, pp. 5-17.]

resources.name: Estimation of the Total Surface Area in Indian Elephants (Elephas maximus indicus)

reason: Their colorful report “The Effects of Pre-Existing Inappropriate Highlighting on Reading Comprehension.” [ PUBLISHED IN: Reading Research and Instruction, vol. 36, no. 3, 1997, pp. 217-23.]

resources.name: The Effects of Pre-Existing Inappropriate Highlighting on Reading Comprehension

reason: Promoting peace and harmony between the species by inventing Bow-Lingual, a computer-based automatic dog-to-human language translation device.
Inventing a washing machine for cats and dogs.

resources.name: washing machine for cats and dogs

reason: Adapting the mathematical concept of imaginary numbers for use in the business world. [NOTE: all companies are U.S.-based unless otherwise noted.]
His excruciatingly balanced report, “Scrotal Asymmetry in Man and in Ancient Sculpture.” [PUBLISHED IN: Nature, vol. 259, February 5, 1976, p. 426.]

resources.name: Scrotal Asymmetry in Man and in Ancient Sculpture

reason: His impactful medical report “InjuriesDue to Falling Coconuts.”
His partial solution to the question of why shower curtains billow inwards.

resources.name: the question of why shower curtains billow inwards

reason: Inventing Under-Ease, airtight underwear with a replaceable charcoal filter that removes bad-smelling gases before they escape.
Their conclusion that people find a way to postpone their deaths if that would qualify them for a lower rate on the inheritance tax.
His efforts to protect, promote, and defend the differences between plural and possessive.
His influential research report “An Ecological Study of Glee in Small Groups of Preschool Children.”

resources.name: An Ecological Study of Glee in Small Groups of Preschool Children

reason: Their discovery that black holes fulfill all the technical requirements to be the location of Hell.

resources.name: Dr. Jack and Rexella Van Impe

reason: Creating the amusement park known as “Stalin World.”

Patenting the wheel in the year 2001, and to the Australian Patent Office for granting him Innovation Patent #2001100012. [NOTE: Several years after this prize was awarded, the patent office quietly revoked Mr. Keogh’s patent.]
Their probing medical discovery that nose picking is a common activity among adolescents.

resources.name: National Institute of Mental Health and Neurosciences

reason: Their modest report, “Unskilled and Unaware of It: How Difficulties in Recognizing One’s Own Incompetence Lead to Inflated Self-Assessments.” [Published in the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, vol. 77, no. 6, December 1999, pp. 1121-34.]

resources.name: Unskilled and Unaware of It: How Difficulties in Recognizing One’s Own Incompetence Lead to Inflated Self-Assessments
Journal of Personality and Social Psychology

reason: Her book “Living on Light,” which explains that although some people do eat food, they don’t ever really need to.
His first-hand report, “On the Comparative Palatability of Some Dry-Season Tadpoles from Costa Rica.” [Published in The American Midland Naturalist, vol. 86, no. 1, July 1971, pp. 101-9.]
Using magnets to levitate a frog. [REFERENCE: “Of Flying Frogs and Levitrons” by M.V. Berry and A.K. Geim, European Journal of Physics, v. 18, 1997, p. 307-13.]

resources.name: Andre Geim won a Nobel Prize in physics

reason: Their discovery that, biochemically, romantic love may be indistinguishable from having severe obsessive-compulsive disorder. [REFERENCE: “Alteration of the platelet serotonin transporter in romantic love,” Marazziti D, Akiskal HS, Rossi A, Cassano GB, Psychological Medicine, 1999 May;29(3):741-5.]

resources.name: Alteration of the platelet serotonin transporter in romantic love

reason: Bringing efficiency and steady growth to the mass-marriage industry, with, according to his reports, a 36-couple wedding in 1960, a 430-couple wedding in 1968, an 1800-couple wedding in 1975, a 6000-couple wedding in 1982, a 30,000-couple wedding in 1992, a 360,000-couple wedding in 1995, and a 36,000,000-couple wedding in 1997.
Their illuminating report, “Magnetic Resonance Imaging of Male and Female Genitals During Coitus and Female Sexual Arousal.” [Published in British Medical Journal, vol. 319, 1999, pp 1596-1600.]

resources.name: Magnetic Resonance Imaging of Male and Female Genitals During Coitus and Female Sexual Arousal

reason: Inventing PawSense, software that detects when a cat is walking across your computer keyboard.
